data.title: Go-kart operator K1 Speed opens first Ohio location near Akron-Canton Airport
data.meta_description: K1 Speed Canton, owned by Jackson High graduate James Burley, opened Wednesday near the Akron-Canton Regional Airport in Jackson Township.
data.text:
JACKSON TWP. – James Burley smiled and then paused.

His dream realized.

"Whew," Burley said, taking a breath. "It's exciting. It's emotional."

Burley owns the newest attraction in the Stark County area, K1 Speed Canton, an indoor electric go-kart track facility that opened Wednesday.

More: K1 Speed go-kart racing coming to Jackson Township

More: Time to hit the (non) ice! Jackson Twp. opens artificial skating rink

K1 Speed Canton is at 8373 Port Jackson Ave. NW near the Center Ice Sports Complex and the Akron-Canton Airport.

It is the first Ohio franchise for K1 Speed, a California-based company and the world's largest indoor go-kart racing operator.

"I think it's nice because the closest place (for indoor, electric go-karts) around here is Medina," said Mitch Shannon, a North Canton resident who raced a couple times.

His friend Matthew Beaber, also of North Canton, added: "It was fun. The turns are challenging but other than it's a good time."

K1 Speed features include hybrid track

The franchise-owned K1 Speed in Stark County will feature the parent company's first hybrid indoor-outdoor track.

The outdoor extension remains under construction.

In the meantime, racers can enjoy the indoor configurations that include 12 laps and adult go-karts that reach speeds of 45 mph. The facility also has junior go-karts for children 4 feet or taller that max out at 20 mph. No one under 4 feet can race.

The track also includes a large LED screen that displays racer times.

K1 Speed Canton also has an eatery that serves food and drinks, a private room for parties or other events and will add an arcade.

Burley said the facility also will host go-kart leagues.

Uli Perez, international franchise manager and operations quality control manager for K1 Speed, has been helping Burley and his crew get the Stark County location open.

"With Mid-Ohio being a local race track out here," Perez said, "there's a lot of racers that I see out here that are going to want to have their kids' birthdays at a race track, something they relate to."

Perez said the facility can be rented for parties.

Staying true to success

Perez said K1 has 55 locations worldwide — 34 are corporate and the rest are franchises — with plans to expand. Among the international locations include Canada, China, Mexico and South Korea.

He said the company's success keeps its focus on its primary attraction.

"We don't veer from what we offer, which is the racing experience and being a family-oriented entertainment facility," Perez said.

Building family relationships

Burley, a Jackson High graduate, has enjoyed a lifelong passion for race cars. It started with his father, George, an engineer, who worked 40 years at Firestone Tire and Rubber Co.

In 1973, his father, now retired, helped create a new machine that labeled "Firestone Firehawk" on Indy Car racing tires. That drew Burley into the sport.

K1 Speed Canton features an Indianapolis 500 race car as its centerpiece display.

Burley said he had an itch to open an go-kart facility locally, and approached K1 Speed with franchise plans. The process took two years but he got the green flag to open Wednesday.

And Burley, a former youth minister, said he hopes his facility won't just entertain but also strengthen bonds between families and friends.

"It doesn't matter if it's dads and sons, moms and daughters, or uncles and aunts," he said. "It doesn't matter the relationship. If a facility like this can build family relationships, then we've done our part."
